Muhammad Ali, born Cassius Marcellus Clay, Jr., in 1942, was a celebrated athlete who achieved numerous milestones in boxing, including winning the heavyweight title three times. Despite his success in the ring, he was stripped of his boxing titles in 1967. Muhammad Ali, a celebrated athlete and three-time heavyweight boxing champion, was stripped of his titles in 1967 for being a conscientious objector to the Vietnam War. Despite facing challenges due to his race and religion, he was later vindicated by the Supreme Court in 1971 and recognized as a champion of the Civil Rights Movement in the United States. Muhammad Ali received numerous awards for his achievements in and out of the boxing ring, including the Dr. Martin Luther King Memorial Award, the Spirit of America Award, the Amnesty International Lifetime Achievement Award, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. He was also honored as "Sportsman of the Century" by Sports Illustrated and "Athlete of the Century" by GQ magazine. Muhammad Ali received several prestigious awards and honors, including being named "Kentuckian of the Century" and "Louisvillian of the Century," receiving the "Boxer of the Century" title, and being recognized by the International Boxing Hall of Fame. He also received honorary doctorate degrees from various institutions and the "Otto Hahn Peace Medal in Gold" from the United Nations Association of Germany for his work with the United Nations and the Civil Rights Movement. Muhammad Ali, despite being diagnosed with Parkinson's Syndrome, dedicated his life to universal human rights and freedom. President Jimmy Carter enlisted Ali's help in diplomatic efforts for human rights in Africa. Ali also traveled to the Middle East to seek the release of hostages during the Gulf War. In the first Gulf War, Muhammad Ali intervened to free 15 US hostages held as human shields. He was later chosen as the "U.N. Messenger of Peace" in 1998. Presidents like George W. Bush and Bill Clinton praised Ali for his dedication to humanitarian causes and peace. Muhammad Ali was known for his advocacy for racial equality, humanitarian efforts, and inspiring millions worldwide. Presidents like Jimmy Carter and Barack Obama praised him as a symbol of international friendship. Ali's perseverance and support from thousands of people encouraged humanity. Muhammad Ali's philanthropic efforts included supporting organizations like The Cradle, Make-A-Wish Foundation, Best Buddies, and Herbert E. Birch Services. He and his wife also founded the Muhammad Ali Parkinson Center, raising over $50 million for Parkinson's research. Muhammad Ali's philanthropic efforts extended to founding organizations like Rock Steady Boxing Foundation and Athletes for Hope. He also established the Muhammad Ali Center in Louisville, Kentucky, promoting respect, hope, and understanding. The Muhammad Ali Center focuses on Ali's life, courage, dedication, and passion for peace. It serves as a global gathering place to celebrate commonalities and advance humanity. Ali provided aid to millions and dedicated much of his time to humanitarian causes. Muhammad Ali, a renowned sports figure and role model, passed away at the age of 74 in 2016. Congress authorizes the presentation of a gold medal to Muhammad Ali for his contributions to the nation. The medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury and then transferred to Ali's wife after the presentation. Additionally, duplicate medals may be created. The Secretary may create duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price covering costs. The medals are considered national medals under US law.
